Comment: It's a very interesting interpretation and precedent that intellectual property recorded in other countries, which is video footage, can fall under the umbrella of tariffs. The good itself and the distribution could very possibly have no financial connection to that country beyond its production. It is instead is owned by private holders, who may have sold/licensed their rights to the intellectual property to American distributors and it may never have even a foreign-owned asset from the get-go. What about intellectual properties like paintings from another country, sold to an American art collector who views or licenses art in magazines?   Once that intellectual property is complete and potentially available to the highest bidder or held by a holding company, there is no continued exchange of goods or with a country that has been tariffed. Unless, of course, there is some kind of share (3% of sales goes to that countries' museum or local tourist department.) In the case of sanctions, it does make sense given they are generating economic activity in that country.. but in the case of tariffs it's a professionally recorded performance that becomes intellectual property. That does not generate the foreign country any measurable or hard financial activity once the movie has been recorded. Plus, the financial activity itself on things such as jobsites or to rent equipment never fell under American domestic tax code in the first place.   What about commercials recorded in other countries? Stock images photographed in other countries owned by American holding companies? *What about videos & photographs from travel agencies and hotels that are recorded in travel destinations and used to generate real hard goods such as booked travel?* Sports broadcasts (F1, international tournaments, soccer matches, etc.,)?
